posts.name: Earnest_T
posts.cooked:
Because all of the systems use the same encryption system. What if we could add an encryption system on top of everything else? Think of it as another layer of security.
So what is already selected? We could add a sha256 or AES512. Or anything else that might be an idea in order to keep the conversation more secure.
I realized I may sound like I‚Äôm super paranoid, but I know that the government methods of encryption attacks are quite extensive. and by government I meet any government within the Planet Earth. maybe even a salt phrase that we could add to our group and that would increase the security

posts.name: üëäüá∫üá∏üî•
posts.cooked: Signal already uses TLS and the Signal Protocol. Adding other layers on top would be superfluous and overcomplicate maintenance and development.

posts.name: Earnest_T
posts.cooked: Superfluous? adding any kind of meat to the system would actually make it stronger. How would it alter maintenance?

posts.name: Talya (she/her)
posts.cooked:
github.com

signalapp/Signal-Android/blob/main/CONTRIBUTING.md?plain=1#L11


      
    
          
  1. # Contributing to Signal Android
    2. 
          
  2. 
          
  3. Thank you for supporting Signal and looking for ways to help. Please note that some conventions here might be a bit different than what you are used to, even if you have contributed to other open source projects before. Reading this document will help you save time and work effectively with the developers and other contributors.
    4. 
          
  4. 
          
  5. 
          
  6. ## Development Ideology
    7. 
          
  7. 
          
  8. Truths which we believe to be self-evident:
    9. 
          
  9. 
          
  10. 1. **The answer is not more options.**  If you feel compelled to add a preference that's exposed to the user, it's very possible you've made a wrong turn somewhere.
    11. 
          
  11. 1. **The user doesn't know what a key is.**  We need to minimize the points at which a user is exposed to this sort of terminology as extremely as possible.
    12. 
          
  12. 1. **There are no power users.**  The idea that some users "understand" concepts better than others has proven to be, for the most part, false. If anything, "power users" are more dangerous than the rest, and we should avoid exposing dangerous functionality to them.
    13. 
          
  13. 1. **If it's "like PGP," it's wrong.**  PGP is our guide for what not to do.
    14. 
          
  14. 1. **It's an asynchronous world.**  Be wary of anything that is anti-asynchronous: ACKs, protocol confirmations, or any protocol-level "advisory" message.
    15. 
          
  15. 1. **There is no such thing as time.**  Protocol ideas that require synchronized clocks are doomed to failure.
    16. 
          
  16. 
          
  17. 
          
  18. ## Building
    19. 
          
  19. 
          
  20. 1. You'll need to get the `libwebp` submodule after checking out the repository with `git submodule init && git submodule update`
    21. 
          
  21. 1. Most things are pretty straightforward, and opening the project in Android Studio should get you most of the way there.
    22.

Signal is already fully secure, has been audited multiple times, and is secure enough to be used by US ‚Äúenemy of the state‚Äù Edward Snowden.
you do not need an extra layer of security, and by adding this configuration most users are likely to decrease their security. you are welcome to create your own fork to use whatever additional layers of security you think you‚Äôre getting, though i‚Äôd recommend making sure you aren‚Äôt actually making yourself more insecure accidentally in the process.

link_counts.title: How secure is Signal? It's good enough for Edward Snowden so good enough for you

posts.cooked:
Earnest1990:

What if we could add an encryption system on top of everything else? Think of it as another layer of security.
We could add a sha256 or AES512. Or anything else that might be an idea in order to keep the conversation more secure. [‚Ä¶] maybe even a salt phrase that we could add to our group

You basically want to add ‚Äúsomething‚Äù, you don‚Äôt know what exactly and how this ‚Äúsomething‚Äù should work, but you want to feel more safe.

Here‚Äôs an excerpt of what Bruce Schneier has to say on this in ‚ÄúApplied Cryptography‚Äù, ch. 15.7 Cascading Multiple Block Algorithms

What about encrypting a message once with Algorithm A and key KA, then again with Algorithm B and key KB? [‚Ä¶] This technique is sometimes called cascading, and can be extended far beyond only two algorithms and keys.

Pessimists have said that there is no guarantee that the two algorithms will work together to increase security. There may be subtle interactions between the two algorithms that actually decrease security.

Even triple encryption with three different algorithms may not be as secure as you think. Cryptography is a black art; if you don‚Äôt know what you are doing, you can easily get into trouble.

The problem is much more complex and there are ways to cascade ciphers but it cant be done just by slapping ‚Äúsha256‚Äù or some ‚Äúsalt phrase‚Äù on top of existing crypto protocols. The best case, you just get less efficient crypto protocol, the worst case you could inadvertently break your existing encryption.

And remember it‚Äôs not like Signal protocol is set in stone and doesn‚Äôt keep up with new threats. Some time ago it got reinforced against quantum computing threat.

Signal Messenger

Quantum Resistance and the Signal Protocol

The Signal Protocol is a set of cryptographic specifications that provides end-to-end encryption for private communications exchanged daily by billions of people around the world. After its publication in 2013, the Signal Protocol was adopted not...

If you feel they don‚Äôt develop it fast enough, it‚Äôs because strong cryptography is difficult and every change and addition needs to be carefully reviewed and vetted before it can be deemed secure.

link_counts.title: Signal >> Blog >> Quantum Resistance and the Signal Protocol

posts.name: Pickle
posts.cooked:
I‚Äôd recommend reading up on the cryptography from Signal‚Äôs documentation. Signal already uses AES and SHA in various places. We cannot simply ‚Äúadd‚Äù a hashing algorithm or a salt phrase to ‚Äúkeep the conversation more secure‚Äù. That doesn‚Äôt make much sense. Implementing another layer of AES would be possible. You could actually do it yourself assuming you handle key exchanges too. Or if you wanted to pre-share a key with your friends that would work too. But why?

Signal is already considered one of if the most secure messaging apps. The team has spent countless hours developing an extremely secure protocol. It‚Äôs already secure enough. To put it into perspective, your suggestion would be like going to the most secure military base in the world and suggesting they add ‚Äúarmed guards‚Äù to make it more secure. Sure, this might make it more secure, but if it‚Äôs already the most secure then it‚Äôs probably redundant and unnecessary.

Additionally, you have to think of security as a chain, where any system is only as strong as the weakest link. If someone wants to compromise your Signal messages, it would likely be easier to exploit a vulnerability in one of the many other applications on your device, then just read the Signal messages once the attacker has local access.

Moreover, if you want to apply your own layer of cryptography on top of the Signal protocol, you can. However, it wouldn‚Äôt make sense. It also wouldn‚Äôt be as easy as ‚Äúadding sha256 or AES512‚Äù like you suggested. If you want to experiment for fun you can use a website like CyberChef along with the ‚ÄúAES Encrypt/Decrypt‚Äù functionality to send your friends messages. This could be a good way to experiment with what you want, however I wouldn‚Äôt do this with any messages you actually want to keep secure. You‚Äôre more likely to leak your keys/messages doing something like this.

Overall, you‚Äôre more than safe just using the Signal app by itself. If you‚Äôre looking to stay even more secure I would recommend using secure operating systems, GrapheneOS for mobile, GNU/Linux based systems for desktop, etc. Your weakest link will not be Signal, so there‚Äôs no need to secure it further.

posts.name: Earnest_T
posts.cooked:
These answers highlight a big problem I have found with message boards and the internet in general: sourcing.
I want to thank everyone for making their explanations easy to understand and including their sources. I was not made to feel like I was stupid, and that helps the community in general.
I now have a better understanding of Signal and the process behind it.
Thank you.

posts.name: Earnest_T
posts.cooked: I‚Äôm glad I could do something to help improve your self esteem. Have a Merry Christmas.

goodec:

but you‚Äôre more annoyingly lazy‚Ä¶
‚Ä¶than stupid.

I think it‚Äôs unnecessarily harsh for Earnest1990. Frankly we‚Äôve all probably been in a situation when we thought we know more on a particular subject than we actually did at some point. And Ernest didn‚Äôt persist he‚Äôs right against all arguments so it‚Äôs big plus.

Anyway, Merry Christmas/Happy Holidays to you too.

posts.name: Whatnoww
posts.cooked:
Sorry you got that sort of reply :(

I don‚Äôt think this represents the community and how we want to treat and inform people that are starting out in the privacy and security space.

i partially like the original idea, but there are some serious catches.

idea might be better for matrix protocol, xmpp or other open standard. where user can select best or better encryption if default is not good enough. but does that encryption replace previous or is it added is up to protocol, maybe both options should be there.

but i‚Äôm not arguing encryption that much, but some other points.

let‚Äôs assume that signal initiates plugins for additional encryption. then those plugins become attack vector for bad security and malicious codes. in worst case scenario, plugin spies users directly. and plugins complicate things. if users do not understand plugins, mishandling of plugins may downgrade security and encryption.

it was said here indirectly, but what about underlying platform like android, windows, ios, linux or other o.s‚Ä¶ sometimes is more important to secure underlying platform than getting perfect communication program. did users get so called perfect operating system !?

posts.name: Pickle
posts.cooked:
zetabeta:

it was said here indirectly, but what about underlying platform like android, windows, ios, linux or other o.s.. sometimes is more important to secure underlying platform than getting perfect communication program. did users get so called perfect operating system !?

I think I said it pretty directly. Signal is already secure, so there‚Äôs no need to worry about securing it further unless a weakness can be found and proven. Anyone is encouraged to look for weaknesses as it will help improve the platform for everyone. As I previously mentioned, users are much more likely to be compromised through a vulnerability in their operating system or another application they use.
